Viscerosomatic reflexes at T10–T11 are primarily associated with the middle gastrointestinal tract. Conditions that affect the middle gastrointestinal tract, such as celiac disease, may manifest as a somatic dysfunction, e.g., tissue texture changes, at the corresponding thoracic segment. Other organs associated with T10–T11 somatic dysfunctions are the adrenal glands, kidneys, proximal ureters, gonads, uterus, and cervix.

D) INCORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T12–L2 are associated with the lower gastrointestinal tract. Conditions involving these organs may manifest with symptoms such as abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fatigue, but they are not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis and positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies.

E) INCORRECT:

The sympathetic nervous system originates in the spinal cord from T1 to L2. The sympathetic nerves do not originate from below the L2 segment.
questions.hint: Postprandial abdominal pain, chronic diarrhea, and fatigue are consistent with a malabsorptive syndrome. The additional presence of dermatitis herpetiformis (several tense, grouped, subepidermal blisters) and serum tissue transglutaminase antibodies suggest celiac disease, which primarily affects the middle gastrointestinal tract including the distal duodenum and proximal jejunum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office with severe pelvic pain that began 1 year ago and has been progressively worsening. She reports that the pain intensifies before menses, and she also experiences dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. Past medical history is unremarkable. She currently has one sexual partner. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use any other substances. Vital signs are normal. Pelvic examination reveals adnexal tenderness and palpable nodules just posterior to the uterus. Structural examination would most likely reveal a viscerosomatic reflex at which of the following spinal segments?

choices.text: T1
T4
T9
T7

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T1 are primarily associated with the head and neck (T1–T4) and the heart (T1–T5), none of which are affected in this patient with endometriosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T4 are primarily associated with the head and neck (T1–T4), heart (T1–T5), respiratory system (T2–T7), and esophagus (T2–T8), none of which are affected in this patient with endometriosis.

C) CORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T10–L2 are primarily associated with the uterus and cervix. Viscerosomatic reflexes at T10–T11 are primarily associated with the ovaries. This patient with endometriosis affecting the uterine appendages and rectouterine pouch most likely has a viscerosomatic reflex (e.g., tissue texture changes) at T10.

See “Overview of the innervation of organs in the autonomic nervous system” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T9 are primarily associated with the upper gastrointestinal tract (T5–T9), including the stomach, liver, gallbladder, spleen, and portions of the pancreas and duodenum. Although the gastrointestinal tract can be affected in endometriosis, its involvement is rare, and a viscerosomatic reflex at another spinal segment is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Viscerosomatic reflexes at T7 are primarily associated with the respiratory system (T2–T7), esophagus (T2–T8), and upper gastrointestinal tract (T5–T9). Although these organs can be affected in endometriosis, their involvement is rare, and a viscerosomatic reflex at another spinal segment is more likely.
questions.hint: Chronic (≥ 6 months) pelvic pain that intensifies before menses combined with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, adnexal tenderness, and rectouteral nodules suggests endometriosis.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the office for evaluation of chronic low back pain. He reports increased discomfort after work, where he spends several hours each day sitting at his desk. He denies any recent injuries. Past medical history is unremarkable. Osteopathic structural examination reveals:

Occipitoatlantal junction rotated left
Cervicothoracic junction rotated right
Thoracolumbar junction rotated right
Lumbosacral junction rotated right

Assuming this patient normally presents with Zink's common compensatory pattern, what is the most likely location of his somatic dysfunction?

choices.text: Occipitoatlantal junction
Lumbosacral junction
Thoracolumbar junction
Cervicothoracic junction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The occipitoatlantal junction rotated left is consistent with Zink's common compensatory pattern. A somatic dysfunction at the occipitoatlantal junction is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The lumbosacral junction rotated right is consistent with Zink's common compensatory pattern. A somatic dysfunction at the lumbosacral junction is unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Individuals with the common compensatory pattern present with the occipitoatlantal junction rotated left, the cervicothoracic junction rotated right, the thoracolumbar junction rotated left, and the lumbosacral junction rotated right. Because this patient presents with the thoracolumbar junction rotated right, his somatic dysfunction is most likely located at this junction. Additionally, this patient's low back pain due to prolonged sitting at work suggests a somatic dysfunction at the thoracolumbar junction.

D) INCORRECT:

The cervicothoracic junction rotated right is consistent with Zink's common compensatory pattern. A somatic dysfunction at the cervicothoracic junction is unlikely.
questions.hint: Zink's common compensatory pattern is the alternating pattern of preferred directions of fascial rotation at four transitional areas in the spine that is observed in approximately 80% of individuals without underlying medical conditions. Individuals with somatic dysfunctions present with uncompensated patterns (i.e., without alternation in rotation).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents to the physician with a 2-month history of fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. She mentions increased stress at her job as an x-ray technician recently due to the high patient load. Her past medical history and family history are unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She does moderate exercise 3 days a week. Vital signs reveal: 


Temperature
37.0°C (98.6°F)


Blood pressure
120/80 mm Hg


Heart rate
80/min


Physical examination reveals:

Generalized pallor
Normal lung sounds

Palpable abdominal mass 5 cm below the left costal margin


Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin concentration of 9 g/dL (reference range: 12.0–16.0 g/dL), a leukocyte count of 95,000/mm3 (reference range: 4500–11,000/mm3), and a platelet count of 600,000/mm3 (reference range: 150,000–400,000/mm3). A peripheral blood smear shows increased numbers of promyelocytes, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Where does sympathetic innervation originate for the organ most likely associated with this patient's abdominal discomfort?

choices.text: T1–T5
T5–T9

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

T1–T5 corresponds to the autonomous level of the heart.

B) CORRECT:

T5–T9 is the spinal cord level that corresponds to sympathetic innervation of the upper gastrointestinal tract, including the spleen. This patient's physical examination reveals splenomegaly, a typical finding in CML that is caused by extramedullary hematopoiesis of migrated malignant cells in the spleen and associated with abdominal discomfort. Conditions affecting the spleen are associated with a viscerosomatic reflex (e.g., paravertebral tissue texture changes) at T5–T9.

See “Overview of the innervation of organs in the autonomic nervous system” table.

C) INCORRECT:

T8–T10 is the spinal cord level that corresponds to sympathetic innervation of the adrenal glands.

D) INCORRECT:

T10–T11 corresponds to the autonomous level of the middle gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, upper ureters, and ovaries.

E) INCORRECT:

T11–L2 corresponds to the autonomous level of the bladder.
questions.hint: The patient's unexplained weight loss, anemia, and leukocytosis with an increased number of progenitor cells (i.e., promyelocytes, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes) raise suspicion for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Her abdominal discomfort is most likely due to splenomegaly.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of neck pain and headaches that began when she started attending college. The headaches are localized to her temples, characterized by dull pressure, and occasionally accompanied by jaw pain. She carries heavy textbooks in her backpack and has had constant neck and upper back pain. Past medical history is unremarkable. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use any other substances. Her vital signs are normal. When standing at ease, she has rounded shoulders and hyperkyphosis of the thoracic spine. Physical examination reveals a taut band of musculature in the posterolateral aspect of the neck that is significantly tender on palpation; light compression results in dull temporal pain similar to the headaches she describes. What is the most likely cause of this patient's pain?

choices.text: Chapman reflex point at T2
Upper trapezius trigger point (TrP1)
Tension-type headache
Trigeminal neuralgia
Temporomandibular joint dysfunction
Posterior thoracic tender point (PT1)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chapman reflex points are discrete nodules that are painful on palpation but do not refer pain. Additionally, Chapman points are associated with visceral dysfunction (e.g., a posterior Chapman point located at T2 is associated with conditions affecting the heart, bronchi, and/or esophagus).

B) CORRECT:

The upper trapezius trigger point (TrP1) refers pain to the ipsilateral temple and jaw and is associated with poor posture, chronic trapezius strain, and tension headaches. The diagnostic criteria of myofascial trigger points include muscle soreness and the presence of a taut band of musculature that reproduces the patient's referred pain when compressed.

C) INCORRECT:

Tension-type headaches can manifest with dull pressing pain affecting the frontal and temporal areas bilaterally and are associated with poor posture and fatigue. Tension headaches are typically episodic and not reproducible with palpation.

D) INCORRECT:

Although trigeminal neuralgia can manifest with facial pain originating from the jaw, affected individuals typically present with severe pain that has a sharp, stabbing quality. Furthermore, additional symptoms, such as psychological distress and facial spasms, are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction can manifest with jaw pain and is associated with headaches and poor posture. Patients with TMJ dysfunction typically present with additional symptoms, such as ear pain, trismus, bruxism, and TMJ clicking or cracking, none of which is seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Tender points are hypersensitive areas within myofascial tissue that are painful on compression but do not refer pain. Additionally, tender points manifest as discrete fingertip-sized tense points, not as taut bands.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are mediated by a reflex that is caused by continuous sensory input from an overstretched muscle spindle that sensitizes the interneurons at its corresponding spinal segment. This reflex results in a taut band of musculature with a characteristic pattern of referred pain.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the office with a 6-month history of difficulty starting urination and a decreased force of the urinary stream. He also mentions that he wakes up multiple times at night to urinate. Medical history includes controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Family history reveals that his father had similar urinary issues in his late sixties. He denies any pain during urination, hematuria, or history of urinary tract infections. Physical examination reveals:

Regular heart rate and rhythm
Clear lung sounds
Soft abdomen with active bowel sounds, no guarding or rigidity
Enlarged, smooth, and firm prostate with no nodules or areas of induration

Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Chapman point at the tip of the 12th rib
T9 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left
T8-T10 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right
Chapman point at the proximal inner thigh
T12 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Chapman point at the tip of the 12th rib on the right is primarily associated with the appendix.

B) INCORRECT:

The spinal segment T9 supplies sympathetic innervation to the upper gastrointestinal tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal segments T8–T10 supply sympathetic innervation to the adrenal glands.

D) INCORRECT:

A Chapman point at the proximal inner thigh is primarily associated with the rectum.

E) CORRECT:

A viscerosomatic reflex is a somatic response to localized visceral stimuli (e.g., irritation) that can manifest as a somatic dysfunction or imbalance of the sympathetic or parasympathetic nervous system. Spinal segments T10–L2 supply sympathetic innervation to the prostate. Therefore, further evaluation of this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia is most likely to show a somatic dysfunction at T10–L2 (e.g., T12 flexed, rotated right, sidebent right).

See “Overview of the innervation of organs in the autonomic nervous system” table.
questions.hint: Difficulty starting urination, a decreased force of the urinary stream, and nocturia, together with an enlarged, smooth, and firm prostate on examination, are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the office because of a 3-day history of fever and shaking chills. She also reports low back pain. Vital signs are:


Temperature
39.4°C (103°F)


Blood pressure
105/70 mm Hg


Heart rate
100/min


Physical examination reveals right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals a WBC count of 80/hpf (reference range: 0-5/hpf). Ultrasound examination of the kidneys shows no signs of obstruction. Which of the following findings is most consistent with a viscerosomatic reflex related to this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Moist skin and increased muscle tone at T8
Cool skin and edema at T9
Erythematous skin and bogginess at T10
Dry skin and fibrotic soft tissue at T11
Warm skin and ropiness at T12

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Moist skin and increased muscle tone at the corresponding vertebrae level may be findings in acute conditions. However, reflexes at T8 are associated with the esophagus, stomach, liver, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, proximal duodenum, and adrenal glands rather than the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Edematous soft tissue at the corresponding vertebrae level may be a finding in acute visceral conditions. However, cool skin is a sign of chronic dysfunction. Furthermore, reflexes at T9 are associated with the stomach, liver, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, proximal duodenum, and adrenal glands rather than the kidneys.

C) CORRECT:

The kidneys are primarily associated with sympathetic viscerosomatic reflexes at T10–T11. An underlying renal condition, such as acute pyelonephritis, can result in segmental facilitation of T10–T11, leading to tissue texture changes; bogginess and erythematous skin indicate acute dysfunction (see “Overview of acute and chronic somatic dysfunctions” table). Other organs associated with T10 somatic dysfunctions are the adrenal glands, proximal ureters, gonads, uterus and cervix, prostate, lower extremities, and the GI tract from the distal duodenum to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.

See “Overview of the innervation of organs in the autonomic nervous system” table.

D) INCORRECT:

T11 somatic dysfunction is associated with the kidneys. However, dry skin and fibrotic soft tissue indicate chronic dysfunction and are not expected findings in acute renal conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Warm skin at the corresponding vertebrae level may be a finding in acute visceral conditions. However, ropiness is a sign of chronic dysfunction. Furthermore, reflexes at T12 are associated with the kidneys, ureters, bladder, uterus and cervix, prostate, and the GI tract from the distal duodenum to the proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.
questions.hint: High fever, chills, costovertebral angle tenderness, and findings of pyuria indicate acute pyelonephritis.
